It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, commonly known as the sedge family, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with slender, erect stems. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, where it forms dense, low-growing clusters. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are usually arranged in spikelets, and the plant plays a role in stabilizing soil in aquatic ecosystems. Fimbristylis riehleana is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to thrive in waterlogged soils.
